summary: This document appears to be a news article or blog post from July 2006, reporting on the ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. It details the legal team assembled by Epstein, allegations of witness intimidation via private investigators, and the state attorney's decision to close the initial investigation, referring it to the FBI. It highlights the high-profile nature of the case and the controversy surrounding the initial handling.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the sex scandal investigation, accused of paying young and underage girls for massages and sexual acts. His legal team is described.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Part of Epstein's legal "dream team," noted for having defended O.J. Simpson and Claus von B端low.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Lead attorney for Epstein. His statement denies allegations about private investigators and claims evidence was submitted to the state attorney. His former clients include Rush Limbaugh and William Kennedy Smith.

persons.name: Jay Goldberger
persons.context: Attorney on Epstein's team who stated that Epstein overwhelmingly passed a lie detector test administered by an expert.

persons.name: Gerald Lefcourt
persons.context: Epstein's New York-based attorney, who defended Russell Crowe and Abbie Hoffman. He commented on the prosecutor's motives.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: Chief of police in Palm Beach. He wrote a letter stating he did not believe police had been served in the case and urged the State Attorney to consider disqualification.

persons.name: Rush Limbaugh
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client of defense attorney Roy Black.

persons.name: William Kennedy Smith
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client of defense attorney Roy Black.

persons.name: O.J. Simpson
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client defended by Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Claus von B端low
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client defended by Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Russell Crowe
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client defended by Gerald Lefcourt.

persons.name: Abbie Hoffman
persons.context: Mentioned as a former client defended by Gerald Lefcourt.

persons.name: Brian Ross
persons.context: ABC News reporter credited with the story.

connections.description: Roy Black is identified as the lead attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, actively defending him and managing the public narrative.
Alan Dershowitz is part of Epstein's legal "dream team" assembled for the sex scandal case.
Jay Goldberger is an attorney on Epstein's legal team who publicly defended him regarding a lie detector test.
Gerald Lefcourt is identified as Epstein's New York-based attorney involved in the case.
Rush Limbaugh is mentioned as a former client of attorney Roy Black.

events.title: News Report on Epstein Investigation
events.description: A news article is published detailing Epstein's legal team, allegations of witness intimidation, and the state attorney closing the initial investigation.

events.title: State Attorney Closes Initial Epstein Case
events.description: The state attorney's office closes the initial sex case investigation, stating no further charges will be brought, and refers the matter to the FBI.

events.title: Alleged Witness Intimidation by Private Investigators
events.description: According to police documents, girls and their families reported being harassed and followed by individuals working for Epstein. One girl's father reported being followed aggressively.

events.title: Epstein's Lie Detector Test
events.description: Defense attorney Jay Goldberger states that Jeffrey Epstein overwhelmingly passed a lie detector test administered by a respected expert.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein assembled a high-profile legal "dream team" including Alan Dershowitz, Roy Black, Jay Goldberger, and Gerald Lefcourt to defend him in the sex scandal investigation.
Police documents alleged that private investigators working for Epstein harassed and followed the young women who accused him and their families, with one father reporting aggressive surveillance.
The Palm Beach State Attorney's office closed its initial investigation into Epstein, stating no further state charges would be brought, and referred the case to the FBI.

Defense attorney Roy Black denied the allegations about private investigators, claiming proof to the contrary was submitted to authorities, while Jay Goldberger claimed Epstein passed a lie detector test.
Police Chief Michael Reiter expressed in a letter that he did not believe police had been properly served in the case and urged the State Attorney to consider disqualification from the prosecution.
